p.s: In the following it will be analyzed how Barack Obama tries to convince his audience that dreams are worth fighting for (ll. 25f.) by examining rhetorical devices.

First of all Obama tries to right in the beginning of his speech to catch the listenerslisteners' attention with the enumeration more separated by geography and ideology; race and religion; wealth and opportunity (ll. 5f.).

He says these words to underline the following paragraph, because there he says that when he traveledtravelled around Iowa and the rest of the country he havehas not been struck by their differences but have been impressed by the values and hopes that they share (ll. 7ff.).
This havehas the effect that the listener now seesees that many persons in America wantswant to live the American Dream and that it may not be like they thought before.
After that he uses an enumeration again: In big cities and small towns; among men and women; young and old, black, white, and brown (ll. 9f.).
Obama wants the listener to understand his point of view and wants to show how same they all are.
He also underlines his words from the first paragraphs and letlets the listener build a graphic mental image, where everyone in America lives together in peace and harmony.
The third important rhetorical device is the anaphora: These are dreams that drove my... (l. 13; l. 17).
The speaker uses these words to show the listener that there were also people before them who wanted the American Dream come true and that they now need to still work on it.
This anaphora havehas the effect that the listener feels more connected to the speaker.
Additionally you can say that Obama also uses this rhetorical device to underline his opinion that the dreams are worth fighting for (ll. 25f.).

Furthermore his last words And I knew dreams are worth fighting for (ll. 25f.) were build up by the called anaphora, so Obama connected the impact of the speech and buildbuilds a bridge to his last words.
Lastly Obama uses the anaphora/repetition: no matter what color you are, no matter where you are from, no matter how much money you have (ll. 19f.).
He claims these words in context with his mother to show the listener that there is a chanechance that everyone can achieve the American Dream just if they are willing to try.
As listener you now maybe believe more in the chanechance of achieving the American Dream and are more motivated to try to claim the barriers to success.
Taking all these analytical aspects into account, one havehas to aim that Barack Obama convinceconvinces the listener pretty well by using rhetorical devices.
He connects and structursstructures his speech good, so the listener could get a good graphic mental image of the American Dream and the listener is also more open to try to work harder on it.
